SAS application that is essentially Enterprise identity as a service we
decided really early on to build the service on public Cloud infrastructure which I'm very glad I've actually having
been here for three years now running exclusively in AWS we've been an AWS
customer long enough to have five availability zones in the U.S standard region that we can use and we've
deployed every component of our application across all five of these
zones and so what that amounts to is a lot of packets flying back and forth among tons of servers and quite a few
different physical data centers and the reason we came into
we started using boundary is really and Dustin touched on this standard
monitoring tools whether it's nagios or xavix or xenos or you even cloudwatch
you really only get high level ethernet statistics and in the public Cloud
you don't have access to the network metal if I were still running my own data centers like I was four years ago
then that'd be a different story I'd have access to the routers and switches I could export the flows I can do all
kinds of things with the the network metal and the access that I'd have but in public Cloud being completely
abstracted away from that we really immediately saw the need for another tool to give us a better View and
boundary is that tool it gives us an unprecedented flow-based view into what's happening with all of these
hundreds of servers that we have and being the the central identity broker and domain controller for our
customers we naturally have some pretty strict requirements about uptime and performance and this ends up translating
into some very tight tolerances in terms of what we can handle in our
inter-instance networking and boundary's been a really great tool to help us get some deeper performance insight into our
ec2 Networks so beyond that there's two use cases
ways we use boundary that I wanted to talk about here the first one that we run into from time to time is
Zone partitions and what will happen is we'll get an alert that's uh essentially
warns us that some app servers for example in U.S east 1A maybe
um have lost sight of their databases in U.S east 1B two different availability zones in U.S east one region of of AWS
and so when we receive that alert and it's not actually causes a problem because these app servers can't talk to
their databases anymore we can go take a look in boundary and I can see the
real-time graph at one second resolution for the conversation that is described by traffic between these two zones I've
never been able to do this with any other tool before and when we look at that we can we can look here at the screenshot and observe a flat line
between these two zones and then that obviously tells us kind of what's going on take a screenshot open at AWS support
ticket hey guys what's going on can you help us out so that has been hugely hugely helpful when
we have any kind of network hiccup uh and you know the scale at which AWS
operates makes it very important for us to have this level of insight into the
shared network resources the next case I wanted to talk about here was what we call mq split brain so
one of the components of our platform is a message queuing subsystem um if anyone on the phone has ever dealt
with message doing subsystems before you you probably understand that when you've got a partition in your
queuing Brokers that can cause all kinds of Havoc with your application and so we
we've seen various conditions where we get to a state where the slave brokers
in our Network start behaving like Master Brokers and this is a situation that we've dubbed split brain and what's
